featuring a tribute to [[Isaac Asimov]]. | editor = [[Michael Shermer]] | editor_title = Editor-in-Chief | frequency = Quarterly | circulation = 50,000 subscribers{{cite web |url=http://www.skeptic.com/the_magazine/contribute.html |title=Contribution Guidelines|newspaper=Skeptic|accessdate=March 5, 2015}} | category = [[List of skeptical magazines|Skeptical magazine]] | company = Millennium Press | publisher = [[The Skeptics Society]] | firstdate = Spring 1992 | country = United States | based = Altadena, California | language = [[English language|English]] | website = [http://www.skeptic.com/ www.Skeptic.com] | issn = 1063-9330 }} '''''Skeptic''''', colloquially known as '''''Skeptic magazine''''', is a quarterly [[science education]] and science advocacy [[magazine]] published internationally by [[The Skeptics Society]], a [[nonprofit]] organization devoted to promoting [[scientific skepticism]] and resisting the spread of [[pseudoscience]], [[superstition]], and [[irrationality|irrational]] beliefs.{{cite web |url=http://www.skeptic.com/about_us/what_we_do/ |title=What We Do |author= |date= |website= |publisher=Skeptic (U.S. magazine) |access-date=March 5, 2015 |quote=}} Founded by [[Michael Shermer]], founder of the Skeptics Society,[http://www.skeptic.com/about_us/meet_michael_shermer.html "Meet Michael Shermer"]. ''Skeptic''. Retrieved March 5, 2015. the magazine was first published in the spring of 1992 and is published through Millennium Press. Shermer remains the Publisher and [[Editor-in-Chief]] of the magazine and the magazine’s Co-publisher and [[Art Director]] is Pat Linse.{{cite web |url=http://www.skeptic.com/the_magazine/masthead.html |title=Masthead, ''Skeptic'' Magazine. |accessdate=1 December 2008}} Other noteworthy members of its editorial board include, or have included, [[Oxford University]] [[evolutionary biology|evolutionary biologist]] [[Richard Dawkins]], [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning scientist [[Jared Diamond]], [[Magician (illusion)|magician]] and [[escape artist]] turned educator [[James Randi|James “The Amazing” Randi]], actor, comedian, and ''[[Saturday Night Live]] '' alumna [[Julia Sweeney]], professional mentalist [[Mark Edward]], science writer [[Daniel Loxton]], [[Lawrence M. Krauss]] and [[Christof Koch]]. ''Skeptic'' has an international circulation with over 50,000 subscriptions and is on newsstands in the U.S. and Canada as well as Europe, Australia, and other countries.{{cite news | url=http://www.vueweekly.com/making_a_living_of_bullshit_detecting/ | title=Making a living of bullshit detecting | publisher=[[VUE Weekly]] |date=August 27, 2008 | first= | last= | accessdate =2008-10-10 }} == History, format and structure == The cover story of the magazine's very first issue paid tribute to [[scientist]] and [[science-fiction]] writer [[Isaac Asimov]]. [http://shop.skeptic.com/merchant.mvc?&Screen=PROD&Store_Code=SS&Product_Code=magv01n1&Category_Code=BIA "Vol. 1 No.1 (Premiere Issue) Tribute to Isaac Asimov"]. ''Skeptic''. Retrieved March 5, 2015. As Asimov wrote a number of stories featuring robots and coined the term "[[robotics]]", the cover of volume 12, #2 (2006), which is devoted to the topic of artificial intelligence, depicts a [[robot]] sitting on a park bench reading that first issue.[http://shop.skeptic.com/merchant.mvc?&Screen=PROD&Store_Code=SS&Product_Code=magv12n2 "Vol. 12 No. 2 Artificial Intelligence"]. ''Skeptic''. Retrieved March 5, 2015. Every issue of the magazine opens with a description of The Skeptics Society and its mission statement, which is to explore subjects such as [[creationism]], [[pyramid power]], [[Bigfoot]], [[pseudohistory|pseudohistorical claims]] (as in the examples of [[Holocaust denial]] and extreme [[Afrocentrism]]), the use or misuse of theory and [[statistics]], [[conspiracy theories]], [[urban myths]], [[witch-hunt]]s, [[mass hysterias]], [[genius]] and [[intelligence]], and cultural influences on science, as well as controversies involving [[protoscience]]s at the leading edge of established science, and even [[fads]] like [[cryonics]] and [[low-carb diet]]s. In addition to publishing the magazine, the Society also: * sponsors lecture series at the [[California Institute of Technology]] * produces and sells tapes of the lectures, as well as other books on pertinent subjects * holds field trips to investigate and research such subjects * conducts social events to promote good-will * provides resources for the public, skeptic organizations (such as [[SkeptiCamp]]{{cite web | url=http://www.skepticamp.org | title=Skepticamp | accessdate =2012-03-21}}) and the media, with which they may approach controversial subjects from a skeptical viewpoint In 2011, the magazine had three regular columnists: [[James Randi]] wrote "’Twas Brillig…," [[Harriet A. Hall]] wrote "The Skep Doc" and [[Karen Stollznow]] wrote "Bad Language".{{Cite news | title=Table of Contents | magazine=Skeptic | publisher=Skeptics Society | url=http://www.skeptic.com/the_magazine/archives/vol16n02.html | volume=16 | issue=2 | accessdate=July 10, 2011 }} The magazine's page count was between approximately 100 and 110 pages until the 2010s. It was reduced to approximately 80 pages with Vol. 16 No. 3 (2011).{{CN|date=March 2018}} {{As of |2018}}, the magazine had two regular columnists: Harriet A. Hall and [[Carol Tavris]].{{cite web|title=Skeptic: CURRENT ISSUE: VOLUME 23 NUMBER 1|url=https://www.skeptic.com/magazine/|website=skeptic.com|publisher=Skeptic Magazine|accessdate=30 March 2018|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330232530/https://www.skeptic.com/magazine/|archivedate=30 March 2018|df=}} === Typical topics === Each issue features an [[editorial]]. In the past this was provided by [[James Randi]], and was often a reaction to stories from mainstream news media such as the 2005 story by the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[newsmagazine]] ''[[Primetime Live]]'' featuring a [[Brazil]]ian [[faith healer]], [[João de Deus (medium)|João Teixeira]].{{CN|date=March 2018}} Other times Randi wrote about topics he had investigated in the past, such as alleged [[dowser]]s,{{cite web|url=https://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/11-08-31/#feature/|title = A Report from the Paranormal Trenches|website=Skeptic.com|publisher=Skeptic Magazine|accessdate=30 March 2018|date = 2011-08-31}} alleged [[psychic]]s like [[Sylvia Browne]], and UFOs.{{CN|date=March 2018}} The magazine also features a large correspondence section called "Forum". This includes not only letters from lay readers but also in-depth comments and rebuttals from [[professional]]s, contributing to extended academic debate across issues raised in past editions.{{CN|date=March 2018}} The bulk of the magazine treats a variety of topics. [[Front cover|Cover stories]] have ranged from examination of alleged [[UFO]]s in [[religious icons]] and theories of the likelihood of [[artificial intelligence]] to tributes to luminaries such as [[Isaac Asimov]] and [[Ernst Mayr]].[[Sulloway, Frank J.]] (February 2005). [http://www.skeptic.com/eskeptic/05-02-11/ "Ernst Mayr, 1904–2005Remembrances & Tribute"]. ''Skeptic''. Some editions feature special sections devoted to a particular topic or theme that is examined through multiple articles by different authors, such as [[intelligent design]] - a frequently recurring topic in the magazine, given the ongoing [[creation vs. evolution controversy]].{{CN|date=March 2018}} {| border=1 | {| class="wikitable" |+ Issues 1-10 ! New episodes of the show are released on a biweekly basis. The show is produced by the original, continuing show hosts ([[Robynn McCarthy]] and [[Derek Colanduno]]) in collaboration with staff of ''Skeptic'' magazine.{{cite news | url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article4470372.ece | title=Podcast of the week: Skepticality offers the 'truth' | publisher=[[The Times]] |date=August 9, 2008 | first=Chris | last=Campling | accessdate=August 6, 2009 }} In 2009, a second official podcast was added. ''[[MonsterTalk]]'' critically examines the science behind [[cryptozoology|cryptozoological]] and [[legendary creatures]], such as Bigfoot, the [[Loch Ness Monster]] and [[werewolves]].{{cite web | url=http://www.skeptic.com/podcasts/monstertalk/ | title=About MonsterTalk | accessdate=July 22, 2011 }} ''Monster Talk'' is hosted by Blake Smith, [[Ben Radford]] and Dr. [[Karen Stollznow]]. '''Stefanus Alliance International (SAINT)''' is a religious freedom and human rights organization with historical roots in Christian missions work, dedicated to defending freedom of belief and religion as expressed in Article 18 of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]]. The organization is based in [[Oslo]], [[Norway]]. Its motto, designated in 1996, is: "Together for the persecuted."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stefanus.no/no/om_oss/english/Stefanus+Alliance+International.9UFRjYYc.ips|title=Stefanus Alliance International|last=|first=|date=|website=Stefanus Alliance International|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-08}}</ref>
==History==
''Stefanus Alliance International'' was established in 1967 by [[Monrad Norderval]], Anutza Moise, Vemund Skard, Else-Marie Skard and Gulbrand Øverbye.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stefanus.no/no/om_oss/kort_historikk/|title=Kort historikk|last=|first=|date=|website=Stefanus Alliance International|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-08}}</ref> It was earlier known as the ''Mission Behind the Iron Curtain'', or the ''Norwegian Mission to the East.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://snl.no/Stefanusalliansen|title=Stefanusalliansen|last=|first=|date=|website=Store Norske Leksikon|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-08}}</ref> The organization decided at its meeting of October 29, 2011 to change its name to ''Stefanus Alliance International'' as of January 1, 2012. <ref>{{cite news|title=Norsk Misjon i Øst skifter navn|page=12|work=Vårt Land|date=31 October 2011|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
==Activities==
''Stefanus Alliance International'' provides support, care, and practical help for churches and individuals who are persecuted or oppressed because of their religious beliefs. The organisation also advocates on behalf of Christians and others who have had their religious rights violated. It commissioned a radio in 1968, published the newspaper ''Ropet fra Øst'' in 1971, and helped establish [[Forum 18]] news service in 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stefanus.no/no/om_oss/kort_historikk/|title=Kort historikk|last=|first=|date=|website=Stefanus Alliance International|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-08}}</ref>
The NGO is a partner in the international [[Christian Solidarity Worldwide]] network since 2001.
''Stefanus Alliance International'' awards the [[Stefanus Prize]], a prestigious human rights prize to individuals who have made an outstanding contribution to the work for freedom of religion or belief as defined by the Article 18 of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]]. Despite having historical roots as a Christian missions organization, ''Stefanus Alliance International'' in awarding the [[Stefanus Prize]] has recognized the efforts of individuals across different faiths.
== Leadership == The organisation is currently led by secretary-general Hilde Skaar Vollebæk.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stefanus.no/no/nyheter/norge/Gravaas+slutter+som+generalsekret%C3%A6r.b7C_wtfS23.ips|title=Gravaas slutter som generalsekretær|last=|first=|date=2017-07-21|website=Stefanus Alliance International|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-07}}</ref> Former secretary generals include Lasse Trædal (1982-1989), John Victor Selle (1989-2002), [[Bjørn Wegge]] (2002-2013) and Hans Aage Gravaas (2013-2017).
On January 3, 2018, ''Stefanus Alliance International'' announced its search for a new secretary-general to replace Hilde Skaar Vollebæk.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stefanus.no/no/nyheter/norge/Vi+s%C3%B8ker+ny+generalsekret%C3%A6r.b7C_wtjW23.ips|title=Stefanusalliansen søker ny generalsekretær|last=|first=|date=|website=Stefanus Alliance International|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-12}}</ref> On April 3, 2018, ''Stefanus Alliance International'' publicized its decision to appoint Ed Brown as the new secretary-general as of August 1, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stefanus.no/aktuelt/ed-brown-ny-generalsekretaer-i-stefanusalliansen/|title=Ed Brown ny generalsekretær i Stefanusalliansen|last=|first=|date=2018-04-03|website=Stefanus Alliance International|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-03}}</ref>
